title: Retro Drive-In Food
description: Roll down the window and remember the carhops, trays, and delicious food from the golden age of drive-in restaurants!

questions.question: What was attached to the car door to hold your food at a classic drive-in restaurant?
questions.explanation: Window-mounted trays (or window trays) were hooked onto the car's rolled-down window by the carhop, creating an instant table for eating in your car.

questions.question: What was the name of the employees who brought food to your car at a drive-in restaurant?
questions.explanation: Carhops, named because they would 'hop' onto the running boards of cars, were the servers at drive-in restaurants. Many wore uniforms and some famously served on roller skates.

questions.question: Which drive-in chain, founded in 1941, became famous for its foot-long chili dogs and carhops on roller skates?
questions.explanation: Sonic Drive-In (originally Top Hat Drive-In, renamed in 1959) became America's largest drive-in chain, famous for its carhop service and extensive menu.

questions.question: What thick frozen beverage was a specialty at many drive-in restaurants in the 1950s?
questions.explanation: Thick milkshakes, often served in tall paper cups or frosted glasses, were the signature drink at drive-in restaurants. Flavors like chocolate, vanilla, and strawberry were standards.

questions.question: What was the standard way to order food at many drive-in restaurants before carhops came to your car?
questions.explanation: At many drive-ins, you would flash your headlights to signal the carhop that you were ready to order. Speaker box ordering systems came later at some chains.

questions.question: Which root beer brand was most closely associated with drive-in restaurants and served in frosted glass mugs?
questions.explanation: A&W Root Beer stands, starting in 1919, served their root beer in trademark frosted glass mugs at drive-in locations across America. The frosty mug became their signature.

questions.question: What classic drive-in food item consisted of a hot dog wrapped in a cornmeal batter and deep fried on a stick?
questions.explanation: Corn dogs were a staple of drive-in menus, state fairs, and roadside stands. The batter-dipped, deep-fried hot dog on a stick was the ultimate American portable food.

questions.question: What type of fries, cut extra thin and served in a paper bag or basket, were a drive-in specialty?
questions.explanation: Shoestring fries, cut extra thin and fried until golden and crispy, were a popular drive-in specialty. They were often served in small paper bags or red plastic baskets lined with wax paper.

questions.question: What decade is considered the golden age of drive-in restaurants in America?
questions.explanation: The 1950s was the golden age of drive-in restaurants, coinciding with America's post-war car culture boom, the growth of suburbs, and teenagers' desire for hangout spots.

questions.question: What condiment trio was standard on every drive-in tray alongside your burger and fries?
questions.explanation: Ketchup, mustard, and relish were the holy trinity of drive-in condiments, available in small paper cups or squeeze packets alongside every burger, hot dog, and fry order.

questions.question: Which drive-in chain was known for its 'steakburgers' and combined a restaurant with a car service model?
questions.explanation: Steak 'n Shake, founded in 1934, was known for its 'steakburgers' made from T-bone, sirloin, and round steak. Their slogan was 'In Sight, It Must Be Right.'

questions.question: What frozen dessert, similar to ice cream but denser and richer, was a specialty at many Midwestern drive-ins?
questions.explanation: Frozen custard, made with egg yolks for extra richness, was a specialty at many Midwestern drive-ins like Ted Drewes in St. Louis and Kopps in Milwaukee.

questions.question: What was a popular drive-in dessert that consisted of soft-serve ice cream dipped in a chocolate shell that hardened instantly?
questions.explanation: The dipped cone featured soft-serve ice cream dipped in a chocolate coating that hardened on contact with the cold ice cream. Dairy Queen popularized this treat at their drive-in locations.

questions.question: What was the typical gathering time for teenagers at drive-in restaurants on weekend evenings in the 1950s?
options: After the movies or games on Friday and Saturday nights
questions.explanation: Drive-in restaurants were the social hub for teenagers on Friday and Saturday nights. Kids would cruise in, show off their cars, meet friends, and hang out until closing time.

questions.question: What classic onion-based drive-in appetizer was made by slicing a whole onion, separating the rings, battering, and deep frying them?
questions.explanation: Onion rings were a beloved drive-in staple, served golden and crispy in a paper-lined basket. They were the perfect companion to burgers and shakes.
